Right to left Add first 0 - {A|B} Then subtract {A|B} If the square root of 64 can equal to more than one values (positive 8 and negative 8), then zero over zero can equal to more than one values too.

It’s not defined, because you can’t divide by 0. What does it mean to write a / 0 = b? Well, it’d mean that there’d have to be a number b so that 0 times b would equal a. Now, if a is not 0 then such a number doesn’t exist, does it? As 0 times any number equals 0. So you can’t even write any such thing; the whole equation is nonsensical. Now how about 0 / 0 = b? This is a bit different; it would mean that there’d have to be a number b so that 0 times b equals 0. Well, that would work, wouldn’t it? It actually works for any number b. But that’s the problem; you don’t have a single number; there are multiple solutions. But talking about division means talking about algebraic operation, which is a Morphism - Wikipedia. And that has either 1 result or isn’t defined (for the arguments) at all. You’d have to define division differently; not as a morphism from e.g. R to R, but as a morphism from R to 2^R (i.e. to a set of subsets of R). In such a case, you could say that the result of a / 0 is an empty set for a != 0 and 0 / 0 is equal to R (it holds for any number). In the other cases, a / b = {c} where c = a / b as usual. But in the standard algebra, it’s simply not defined.
